title: 112_hr718
content: The "Huntington's Disease Parity Act of 2011" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress finds that Huntington's Disease is a progressive neurological condition causing physical and mental deterioration in approximately 30,000 individuals in the US, with 200,000 more at genetic risk. There is currently no effective treatment to halt or slow the disease's progression, with clinical indicators including loss of movement control and cognitive impairment. Huntington's Disease is a progressive neurological condition with clinical indicators such as loss of movement control, cognitive impairment, and behavioral changes. Adult-onset typically results in the progression of the disease. Personality changes, irritability, mood swings, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive behavior, inability to concentrate, decreased motivation, and severe depression are common symptoms of Huntington's Disease. The disease can manifest in adults between 30 and 50 years of age, with late-onset cases occurring after 50 years and juvenile cases affecting individuals under 19 years old, progressing more rapidly. Huntington's Disease can manifest in adults between 30 and 50 years of age, with late-onset cases occurring after 50 years and juvenile cases affecting individuals under 19 years old, progressing more rapidly. Due to the incapacitating nature of the disease, individuals with Huntington's Disease are unable to work and often rely on Social Security Disability Insurance. Despite medical advancements, the disease still poses challenges for affected individuals. The Social Security Administration has not updated its rules for evaluating neurological disabilities since 1985, specifically for Huntington's Disease. The term "Huntington's Chorea" used by the administration is outdated and inaccurate, failing to acknowledge the full impact of the disease on behavior and cognition. Many individuals with Huntington's Disease rely on Social Security Disability Insurance due to their inability to work. The term "Huntington's Chorea" used by the Social Security Administration is outdated and medically inaccurate, as it does not fully recognize the behavioral and cognitive impact of Huntington's Disease. Individuals with Huntington's Disease must wait 24 months after qualifying for Social Security Disability Insurance before receiving benefits under the Medicare program. After qualifying for Social Security Disability Insurance, individuals with Huntington's Disease must wait 24 months before receiving Medicare benefits. In 2000, the Centers for Medicaid & Medicare Services waived the waiting period for ALS patients, a condition similar to Huntington's Disease. In 2000, the Centers for Medicaid & Medicare Services waived the 24-month waiting period for individuals disabled by ALS, a condition similar to Huntington's Disease. There is an urgent need to revise the outdated Social Security Disability Insurance guidelines for Huntington's Disease due to the significant incapacitation faced by individuals with this condition. Individuals with Huntington's Disease face cognitive, behavioral, and physical incapacitation. There is a need to revise the medical criteria for disability determination and remove the 24-month waiting period for Medicare coverage, similar to ALS patients. Revision of medical and evaluation criteria for evaluating disability caused by adult-onset and juvenile Huntington's Disease. The Commissioner of Social Security will update the criteria for evaluating disability caused by Adult-Onset and Juvenile Huntington's Disease in consultation with medical experts. The Act will amend sections of the Listing of Impairments to provide medical and evaluation criteria for Huntington's Disease in adults and children. The Act will amend the Listing of Impairments to provide medical and evaluation criteria for Huntington's Disease in adults and children, including Juvenile Huntington's Disease. Amendments will be made to the Listing of Impairments to include medical and evaluation criteria for Juvenile Huntington's Disease. The term "Listing of Impairments" refers to appendix 1 of part 404 of title 20 of the Code of Federal Regulations. Amendments to the Social Security Act waive the 24-month waiting period for Medicare coverage for individuals diagnosed with Huntington's Disease. This amendment is effective for benefits under title XVIII of the Social Security Act starting after the enactment of the Act.
